;1943 年 9 月，艾尔莎·莫兰特 (Elsa Morante) 和她的丈夫、小说家阿尔贝托·莫拉维亚 (Alberto Moravia) 逃离了位于罗马除了背上的衣服和一些沙丁鱼罐头之外什么也没有。贝尼托·墨索里尼被他自己的大议会废黜，德国军队占领了意大利首都，开始了为期九个月的占领。这两位作家有很多值得担心的事情：他们都是犹太血统，而摩拉维亚是法西斯主义的直言不讳的批评者，他得知自己即将被捕。这对夫妇的旅程最终将他们带到了丰迪城外山坡上建造的一间单间小屋。他们只带了两本书：《圣经》和“;卡拉马佐夫兄弟;，”;后者;他们将其用作卫生纸。

;

;在随着天气开始变冷，莫兰特需要更暖和的衣服，十月份，莫兰特回到罗马的公寓，收拾了一箱补给品。她勇敢的差事别有用心：当这对夫妇逃跑时，她把自己正在写的一本小说的手稿留在了朋友、电影制片人卡洛·卢多维科·布拉加利亚(Carlo Ludovico Bragaglia)的手中，她想确保它的安全。她对所发现的东西感到满意，回到了小屋，她和摩拉维亚一直躲在那里，直到第二年春天被一名美国中尉释放。四年后，莫兰特一直在创作的小说以“Menzogna e Sortilegio”或“;谎言与巫术;。”;

;
;
;;;;本周我们阅读的最佳书籍;;;< p >;;阅读我们每周三更新的著名小说和非小说类新书评论。;

;

;

;现在，《谎言与巫术》首次推出完整英文版，由珍妮·麦克菲 (Jenny McPhee) 进行了令人兴奋的新译本。 （莫兰特认为这是“残害”的英文删节版，于 1951 年出版，名为“House of Liars”。）乍一看，它几乎没有留下其制作历史条件的痕迹。小说出版时，意大利文学文化以新现实主义为中心。这种风格的实践者，包括摩拉维亚，摒弃了法西斯宣传的优雅、诡计和浮夸，用平实的语言来传达战争的破坏和战争留下的支离破碎的社会。 《谎言与巫术》在很多方面都是新现实主义的反面。这部小说是一部关于社会攀登和注定的浪漫的情节剧传奇，其主题和风格都是故意不合时宜的。其美好时代的背景、广泛的人物阵容、频繁的旁白以及夸张的言辞，使其牢牢地继承了十九世纪小说的传统。它关心的不是真相，而是谎言：闪闪发光的表面、隐藏的身份和愚蠢的伪装。​​

;

;然而，正如莫兰特一再提醒我们的那样，外表往往具有欺骗性。尽管表面上是十九世纪，但《谎言与巫术》只能写于二十世纪。莫兰特对她在同胞中看到的自私和肤浅的仇恨使这部小说充满活力。书中的人物对等级制度的受虐崇拜、偶像崇拜倾向和对媚俗的敏感，体现了她认为使墨索里尼崛起的特征。

;

;莫兰特的小说由年轻女子埃莉莎叙述，她声称自己一直是墨索里尼的成功者。由一个“对小玩意疯狂偏爱”的家庭编写了一个“充满谎言的剧本”。尽管她出生时没有财富或地位，但她的母亲和祖母仍然对自己的社会重要性抱有悲惨的妄想信念，并顽固地执着于旨在排除他们的阶级制度。这种信念以各种方式折磨着他们，破坏了他们的思想以及他们与他人的联系。它也折磨着埃莉莎，她没有继承她祖先的崇高地位，但却继承了他们与真理的不安关系。从很小的时候起，她就更喜欢与自己编造的故事为伴，而不是与其他人的故事为伴。这开始是一种虚幻的闲散习惯，最终转变为一种消耗一切的平行幻想生活，使她与现实隔绝。

;

;这本书以一种矛盾的巫术开始，一种魔术行为，也是驱魔。埃莉莎最近因她的监护人罗莎莉亚的去世而第二次成为孤儿，罗莎莉亚是一名小妓女，在她父母过早去世后收养了她。这次失去亲人的经历引发了埃莉莎关于她亲人的大量回忆，其中充满了她无法亲眼观察到的细节。她将自己新发现的洞察力解释为“像忠实的秘书一样”记录这些故事的必要条件。但对于莫兰特来说，写作是一门融合了背叛和奉献的艺术。 Elisa 的目标不是保存。相反，她希望通过追溯这段家族历史，消灭摧毁她祖先生活的“疯狂的贪婪”。

;

;小说中众多幻象受害者中的第一个是艾丽莎的祖母塞西拉，她是一名引诱的家庭教师。当地一位名叫特奥多罗的贵族想要超越自己的地位。塞西拉被特奥多罗奢华的外表所迷惑，没有注意到他放荡的明显迹象，比如他衣衫褴褛、醉酒的车夫，直到为时已晚。结婚后，他的家人与他断绝了关系，债权人也胆大包天。这对夫妇原本计划住在科尔索的一栋别墅里，但很快就只剩下铁轨旁的一间小公寓。塞西拉被逐出天堂，站在橱窗前，陈列着她再也买不起的物品，“就像夏娃在伊甸园紧闭的大门前一样。”

;
;
;

;莫兰特对这种唯利是图的愿望的蔑视是显而易见的。塞西拉的处境可能很可怜，但她的性格却并非如此。当特奥多罗失去了等级特权时，她的怨恨如此之大，导致她的情感和身体毁容。莫兰特散文中巴洛克式的极端主义放大了她由此产生的怪物：“她似乎被这种毒药陶醉了，细细的蓝色静脉在她娇嫩的皮肤下肿胀，她的瞳孔放大，仿佛被她自己的仇恨形象所迷惑。”

;

;艾丽莎的母亲安娜继承了塞西拉的仇恨和对卓越的渴望。尽管她是“父系血统的完美女性典范”，但她的特权却被系统性地剥夺——像她母亲一样，她觉得这种有辱人格的处境是无法忍受的。这种共同的不满并没有使他们成为盟友；而是让他们成为盟友。塞西拉让女儿成为她压抑愤怒的目标，经常挤压她的手指或将指甲插入安娜的手腕。与此同时，安娜认为她的母亲是她父亲毁灭的原因，而不是受害者。她梦想着有一天，她的贫困得到补救，她将“进入那些乘坐马车在科尔索大道上、住在豪宅里的女士们和先生们的超人领域”。正如埃莉莎从一开始就警告我们的那样，这个故事是“一个怪诞且不确定的案件”，而不是一个救赎案件，安娜注定要下降——但不是在与她的表弟爱德华多发生婚外情之前，驱逐特奥多罗的显赫家族的后裔，激发了她命运多舛的显赫希望。

;
;
;

;莫兰特对意大利阶级制度的描述同样源于她对左派的同情和抵制教条。 《谎言与巫术》中的可怜人物并不是浪漫的英雄，而是几乎都是悲惨、粗俗和贪婪的。富人都是虐待狂，爱德华多尤其如此。他由近乎乱伦的溺爱母亲抚养长大，他内化了一种与生俱来的至高无上的感觉。他的“统治本能常常导致他去爱那些比自己地位低的人”：小狗、家庭教师、像安娜这样的女孩。

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;
;
;

;安娜将爱德华多的浪漫关注视为她自己崇高地位的证明。但他无意通过婚姻，或者任何其他方式来提高她在公众心目中的地位。相反，他渴望她“在精神上吸收她的卑微，这样他就能看到那个骄傲的人在他面前顺从和颤抖”。在一个令人痛苦的镜头中，他用卷发棒烫伤了她的脸颊，这样其他男人就无法欣赏她完美无瑕的美丽。比这种随意的残忍行为更令人不安的是安娜从他手中的“灼热的疼痛”中获得的近乎色情的快感。

;

;当爱德华多不可避免地厌倦了安娜，将她抛弃到不幸的女人的垃圾堆中时，想象自己是他的情人，她就完蛋了。无奈之下，她同意嫁给弗朗西斯科，一位来自农村的贫困学生，她被她那假装的贵族冷淡所迷惑。他只想“证明自己配得上她，并促进她为之而生的荣耀”。但这对夫妇对安娜的显赫地位的共同信念注定了他们的不幸福。安娜无法原谅弗朗西斯科出身低微，也无法原谅他不是爱德华多。她嫁给的男人和她想要的生活之间的差异最终让她发疯。弗朗西斯科在对安娜的崇拜中，拒绝了一个不关心他不光彩的出身的女人的爱：埃莉莎的最终监护人罗莎莉亚。弗朗西斯科和安娜沉浸在各自的幻想中，很少关注他们唯一的女儿。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;莫兰特所描述的累积的愚蠢行为所产生的影响远远超出了家庭范围。它与任何形式的团结背道而驰。莫兰特通过弗朗西斯科这个人物，对政治理想在自利面前的脆弱性提出了尖刻的评论。在与安娜纠缠之前，他在酒馆里度过了空闲时间，向任何愿意倾听的人传播马克思主义。

;

;对于莫兰特来说，弗朗西斯科缺乏决心就是一个症状。 1945 年，墨索里尼被暗杀几天后，她在日记中写道，他的权力取决于这样一个事实：如果要在彼此的责任和个人利益的机会之间做出选择，意大利人每次都会选择后者。直到父亲去世后，母亲患病，埃莉莎才意识到家人自我孤独的真正代价。 “为了让自己与她所处的简陋社区区分开来，我母亲在我们周围竖起了一堵冰冷而充满怨恨的墙，”她想。 “如果大楼里的另一个家庭发生了类似的悲剧，熟人的朝圣活动就会立即开始，我们的房间里就会响起悲伤的哀嚎。”莫兰特的观点很明确：她所描绘的人物渴望得到永远不会接受的机构或个人的接受，从而排斥了那些可能与他们有共同事业的人。

;

;在莫兰特的作品中，这种孤独感贯穿其中。女性的体重往往最重。通常，孤立感会驱使他们做出一些让读者难以理解的行为。莫兰特对女性，尤其是母亲的描绘，引起了批评者的分歧。一些人认为她小说中的“坏”母亲表现出对其他女性的低评价，另一些人则认为她试图揭示女性气质和理想化的母性作为社会结构。 《谎言与巫术》在这个问题上通常是模棱两可的。小说中的女性大多是母亲，她们都遭受苦难，但她们的不幸并没有使她们更倾向于同情其他女性。相反，他们会愤怒、生闷气；他们陷入否认；他们忽视自己的女儿，迷恋自己的儿子。也许并不奇怪，莫兰特与她自己的母亲艾尔玛的关系很困难。据报道，莫兰特曾经在她母亲的门下塞了一张纸条，称她为;maledetta;（“被诅咒的人”），但后来又带着第二张纸条回来，称她为;benedetta; >;（“有福的人”）。

;

;渗透到她生活和工作中的对母亲的矛盾心理并没有阻止一些意大利女权主义者声称莫兰特是“我们所有人的母亲”之一，用一位意大利人的话说米兰妇女书店集体于 1982 年出版的有影响力的书。她最具象征意义的女儿中最著名的无疑是;Elena Ferrante;，其笔名通常被认为是向莫兰特致敬。费兰特曾说过，《谎言与巫术》是“通过这本书，我发现一个完全女性的故事——完全是女性的欲望、想法和感受——可能会引人入胜，同时具有巨大的文学价值。”她似乎从莫兰特那里得到了许可：雄心勃勃地写关于女性的长篇大论，而不需要道歉或担心丑陋。在 ;那不勒斯四重奏;。费兰特对“邻居”中的暴力和贫困的坦率描述让人回想起莫兰特在《谎言与巫术》中对埃莉莎及其家人的肮脏生活、他们破烂的衣服和花哨的小玩意的严格关注。这两部作品都反映了物质匮乏条件下仿制奢侈品的吸引力，以及长期缺乏的社会和情感影响。

;
;;

;费兰特臭名昭著的隐居也可能要归功于莫兰特，莫兰特反对对她的作品进行传记式阅读，尽管她的作品随意借鉴了生活。在 1972 年的一次采访中，莫兰特坚称“作家的私生活就是八卦，无论谁冒犯了我”；她留下了很少的个人文字，仿佛是为了先发制人地阻止任何窥探。尽管她并不否认小说中有她自己的元素，但她坚持认为“生活中的事实如何发生并不重要，重要的是如何讲述这些事实。在书中，事实总是有意识或无意识的伪装，但这种伪装就是事实。 。 。 。就我而言，我不想被视为一个活着的人。”

;

;这句话让艾丽莎在《谎言与魔法》中的命运有了不同的看法。逃避小说，将其理解为比现实更诚实——小说将其呈现为一种心理应对策略，会带来严重的个人和政治后果。但是，正如莫兰特所知，奇幻也是文学的基础。埃莉莎的母系遗传——她称之为她的“疯狂”——正是迫使她写作的原因。 “成为欺骗的奉献者和弟子！把你的每一个想法和你所有的知识都固定在谎言上！ 。 。 。这就是我的存在！”她在书的开头几页中哀叹道。发明是她从未真正摆脱的一种强迫。但哪个坚定的小说家愿意这样做呢？ ♦

;一个女孩是她从雾蒙蒙的车窗往外看，环视着黑暗、安静的道路，这些道路标志着一座已经入睡的小镇。外面，唯一出现的颜色是朦胧的黄色和橙色路灯。她正在夜空中寻找小海雀，或“海雀”，它们从悬崖上掉进小镇。少年环顾四周，寻找白色的飞舞——因为在黑暗中可以看到鸟儿明亮的肚子。在迁徙高峰期，在崎岖的冰岛韦斯特曼纳群岛上，鸟类的数量超过了人类的数量。她是 Vestmannaeyjar 岛上的年轻人之一，在夏天的几周里，她带着仍在适应飞行的海雀宝宝，从陆地飞向它们所属的海洋。

;

;这一传统历史悠久。当韦斯特曼纳亚尔引入电力后，依靠月光导航的海雀变得困惑，并跟随人造光进入内陆而不是出海。杰西卡·毕肖普 (Jessica Bishopp) 的冥想短片《海雀》由爱丽丝·休斯 (Alice Hughes) 和甘尼什·拉贾 (Gannesh Rajah) 制作，展示了在生物多样性丧失等当地环境问题的背景下，日益重要的救援行动。

;
;
;

;而且雏鸟并不是唯一的那些从救援中受益的人。这部短片让我们沉浸在两个十几岁女孩塞尔玛和比尔塔的生活中，跟随她们寻找海雀的旅程，反思她们与自己称之为家的岛屿的联系。韦斯特曼纳亚尔的年轻人寻找掉在街道、院子和社区中的丢失的海鹦鹉，并将它们运送到水里。毕肖普告诉我，女孩和海鹦鹉之间的关系是“内在的、与生俱来的，这就是我感兴趣的原因”。 “他们如此热衷于拯救鸟类，因为他们担心未来，他们希望保护和保护现有的东西。”

;
;
;

;这部电影包括几个片段Birta 和 Selma 在夜晚最黑暗的时刻（通常是凌晨 11 点到 3 点）与朋友开车兜风的镜头。车上充满了期待，女孩们和她们的朋友们仔细地审视着外部环境，向外张望，甚至在她们互相交谈的时候也是如此。在许多对青少年的电影描绘中，半夜开车意味着即将发生的恶作剧，但这些场景颠覆了对叛逆的期望，取而代之的是一种责任感：寻找并收集纸箱里的海雀。开车时，青少年很安静；他们的平静常常被有人惊呼“噗噗！”的声音所打破。当汽车急刹车停下来时，一行人冲出去进行调查。 “我不知道如果我们不救他们会发生什么，”塞尔玛一边说着，一边听着挡风玻璃雨刷器的节奏。 “但我认为他们只会死。”

;

;在令人费解的搜索中穿插着日常生活中的短暂时刻：我们看到塞尔玛与她的朋友谈论丙烯酸指甲，还给她妹妹编辫子。这些场景说明了青少年的环保行动只是更广泛的日常护理的一部分，揭示了一个环境保护既正常又必要的世界。 “我认为我们讲述少女时代的另类故事很重要，而且它不是由创伤或浪漫主导的，”毕肖普说。女孩们表现出自己是负责任的管家。他们也正处于自己的成年期，他们意识到自己的经历与与父母分离的鸟类的经历之间有相似之处。

;

;毕肖普花了很长时间与他们相处比尔塔、塞尔玛和他们的家人远离镜头，想要制作一部以个人、亲密的方式讲述气候行动力量的电影。 “我们看过很多从专家主导或激进主义角度出发的电影，但人们不一定能看到它与他们的关系，”毕肖普说。 “[Birta 和 Selma] 不是活动家或专家。他们是年轻人，他们有自己的梦想和希望，但不一定与环境直接相关。它向我们展示了我们之间的相互联系以及我们如何成为野生动物的一部分。”

;;三．迷失;

;

;当我和我的船员们看着食物在泰晤士河上漂走时，我想知道我的力量是否会随着人们的饥饿加剧而减弱。就像读懂了我的心思一样，Teehy McGann 宣布他找到了一桶面粉，这桶面粉在一阵风中没有被抛到海里。

;

;配给很重要，所以我宣布每个人都可以“一爪子满了，一点也没有”。我坚持要求船员们在指挥官面前用餐。但我们很快发现面粉被污染了，对一个男人来说，他们呕吐的力量如此之大，以至于一些呕吐物溅到了岸上妻子的衣服下摆上。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;我没有生气，而是对呕吐的人感到同情。我用了一种古老的水手技巧，把一块死猪的脂肪绑在一根绳子上，让每个船员吞下它，然后把它拉回来——以安顿他的胃。但任何善行都会受到惩罚。他们会立即要求喝一口水来冲洗呕吐物和猪油，而我则把所有的淡水桶都扔到了船上。 “我不知道该对你说什么！”我会大喊大叫，然后命令他们在背上抽二十下。

;
;
;

;McGann 问我是否感觉良好关于我们目前的方向。我没有受过很深的导航技术教育，但我通过观察父亲了解了基本知识。我眯着眼睛看着太阳，然后把一根打结的绳子浸入水中，低声自言自语着数字。我告诉麦甘，“我们已经在航线上了，明天这个时候我们将穿越赤道——那个肮脏的妓女！”麦甘似乎很怀疑，但其他一些人欢呼雀跃，那感觉很棒。

;

;自我们推出以来，第一次士气高昂。我们失去了一些好人，但我的计算使我们比计划提前了几周。麦甘指出，你仍然可以在威尔斯街上看到敦刻尔克的服装店，这将使我们距离码头不到一海里。 （确实，大约两百英尺。）

;

;我一边听着他的观点，一边抚摸着我的小黑胡子。如果麦克甘是对的，那我就是个傻瓜。我又把绳子浸入水中。

;

;“你不对，我也不对，”我说。 “我们只是迷路了。”

;

;McGann 看起来很害怕或沮丧。

;

;“队长！”有人哭了。 “来看看这个！”

;

;“讨厌的”奥尼尔（后来我给他起了个绰号）指出，许多船员的胳膊和腿上都有深紫色的斑点。事实上，三分之二的人上船时都患有坏血病。尽管生活在陆地上，他们已经几个月没有吃过橙子了——三分之二的人没有吃过！过去几个月没有一个橙子。或者甚至在他们的饮料中喷一点酸橙。他们只是不知道这是一件好事。

;

;患者遭受关节疼痛、牙齿脱落和眼睛出血。 Broken bones that had healed years ago snapped again, collectively causing a steady bone-popping sound that was admittedly distracting to me as I looked over the weird maps and tried to identify how close we were to the Tahitian women. (I was starting to wonder whether we should abandon the South Pole of it all and just head straight to Polynesia.)

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;We soon found that randomly snapping bones was one of the more desirable manifestations of the brutal affliction. Some unfortunate men had their brains swell and pop inside their skulls. Thankfully, the cerebral mush often settled in such a way that the sailor could still walk around and do basic tasks (and no longer remember their name or who they were related to, which made me jealous!). But some pieces of the shattered brain would become lodged in the nasal canals and have to be discharged. Hence the modern-day expression “He's so dumb, he could blast his brain out in one sneeze.”

;
;
;

;The stress of the situation began to wear at the mental stability of the healthy men. Shorty McMolty pranced around the deck, singing, “I'm a prince and it's my birthday!” Moments later, Pally MacMurter marched around with a mop on his head, saying that he was a Jamaican woman and it was Christmas. The men accused Pally of basically doing what Shorty had done but changing it a little bit. He pointed out that he really had been to Jamaica and it had come from that, but then threw up and died.

;
;
;

;The scurvy-ridden men below deck began to succumb as well. Although the deaths were coming more rapidly, I treated each one equally. Every fallen crewman was wrapped in the Union Jack and lowered into the water with prayers and a full gun salute. Their wives then waded into the Thames and dragged them ashore, sometimes nobly heaving the wet flag back on deck so it could be used on the next fallen hero.

;

;One can only imagine their horror when they unwrapped their husbands to find that rats, shipworms, and ratworms had eaten much of their beloveds' faces, regardless of how recently they'd passed. The hungry buggers lacked patience and tact. Indeed, it was a very lucky woman who was able to gaze upon her husband's full dead face as she dragged it ashore.

;

;I started to unravel a bit myself. Apparently, I was heard saying that I “never really wanted this job” and that I was “really scared of big waves.” This was said to be bad for morale. But, worst of all, my sob-screams were heard by my father. He furrowed his brow in disappointment. ♦

;Last month, some four hundred and fifty Catholic leaders from around the world—cardinals, archbishops, bishops, priests and nuns, professors and students, laymen and women—came together in Rome for four weeks of structured conversations. It was one phase of an effort that began with national surveys of Catholics, in 2021, and will conclude in Rome next fall. The whole thing is known as the Synod on Synodality, after a Greek term for coming together.. Pope Francis, who called for the synod, opened and closed the proceedings with Masses at St. Peter's's Basilica and, on many days, joined the conversations, which were held in the Vatican audience hall.

;

;The daily sessions were off limits to the media, but during the last week of talks I spoke with participants at nearby coffee bars and pilgrim houses. By that point, although the conversations had been going on for three weeks, it seemed that no one was yet sure what, exactly, the Synod on Synodality was meant to be. Was it a formal synod of bishops, as defined in the early nineteen-sixties, at the Second Vatican Council, or an informal assembly? Was it about the state of the Church, or about Church governance, or about a renewal in the everyday lives of Catholics—which, in the United States, involve issues such as marriage, sexuality, gender and economic inequality, and the climate emergency? And could it have any real effect, given that a synod is convened not to set policy but to make recommendations to the Pope? None of that was clear. One participant noted that it was hard to know whether the synod was being over-managed, or not managed enough.

;

;What was clear going in was that this synod could have been a capstone to ;Francis's first decade; as Pope. More than his recent predecessors, Francis has used interviews and one-to-one meetings to communicate his prerogatives. Shortly after his election, in March, 2013, he struck a note of progressive reform, asking, in reference to Vatican II, “Have we done everything the Holy Spirit was asking us to do during the Council?” He answered no and warned, “We don't want to change, and, what's more, there are those who wish to turn the clock back.” A few months later, speaking with the Jesuit Antonio Spadaro, the Pope spelled out his sense of what synodality is. Formally, it is a third leg of the Church's authority structure, along with primacy (papal authority) and collegiality (the obligation of the Pope, as bishop of Rome, to work with other bishops). Informally, it is a way of going about things. “It seems to me that the current method is not dynamic,” Francis said. “We must walk united with our differences—there is no other way to become 'one.' ”

;

;Other synods during his tenure—on the family, in 2014 and 2015, and on the Pan-Amazon region, in 2019—foundered because of resistance from traditionalists. The cardinals who organized this one—Mario Grech, of Malta, and Jean-Claude Hollerich, of Luxembourg—saw to it that the more than two hundred voting delegates nominated regionally were joined by about a hundred and twenty others chosen by Francis, a move that some saw as a papal effort to outmaneuver his traditionalist adversaries. Notably, nearly a fifth of the voting delegates were women, a proportion without precedent. In an interview with the Argentinean news agency Télam (given in late September, and published during the synod), Francis highlighted his hopes for the proceedings, saying, “John XXIII had a very clear perception: the Church has to change. Paul VI agreed, just like the succeeding Popes. It's not just about changing ways, it's about a change of growth, in favor of the dignity of people.” So there was widespread expectation that this synod might address issues which have been simmering for the past decade, such as ;the rights of LGBTQ people; and the role of women in the Church, and that the tensions between traditionalists and progressives ;might finally rise; to open confrontation.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;They didn't. The gathering proved to be a meta affair, more about process than substance. For several hours most mornings, the participants sat in groups of about a dozen at round tables and discussed topics derived from preparatory sessions, organized by themes such as including Communion, participation, and mission. The sessions followed a process meant to foster discernment, through listening and “Conversation in the Spirit,” which usually included brief remarks by the participants; responses; and several rounds of silent prayer. The groups produced a series of statements, which were consolidated into a summary report that was then presented to the assembly for amendments (more than twelve hundred in all) and approval. The process was circular: through listening, the participants strove to make Catholicism a “listening” Church rather than a commanding and demanding one; through the synod, they would learn how to proceed more synodally.

;

;What did they talk about? Only the participants know. At the start, Francis enjoined them to undertake a “fasting from speaking in public”—that is, to maintain confidentiality. Nevertheless, some particulars trickled out. One participant spoke about a young LGBTQ person who was made to feel unwelcome by Church officials and died by suicide. Cardinal Gerhard Müller, a German traditionalist who has tilted against Francis again and again, broke the fast by giving an interview in which he claimed that the synod had been rigged. “All is being turned around so that now we must be open to homosexuality and the ordination of women,” he said. A traditionalist cleric walked out of a session, lest he be photographed sitting next to James Martin, an American Jesuit who advocates for LGBTQ Catholics. During week two, a briefing indicated that the synod had affirmed opposition to homophobia, but a participant told me that the sessions on the topic had been “brutal.” (After the synod, Archbishop Andrew Nkea Fuanya, of Cameroon, said, “In Africa, we understand marriage as a union between a man and a woman, and anything short of that is witchcraft,” adding, “This is something we said very strongly.”)

;
;
;

;One justification offered for the “What happens in the Vatican stays in the Vatican” approach was that details shared by individual participants would undermine the clarity of the synod's summary report. “It's going to be flat, which is a shame, because the conversations were not,” one of the report's drafters, Bishop Shane Mainlay, of Sandhurst, Australia, told me near the end of the synod, adding that he wished that he and colleagues could devote another week to it. The report, which was released on the final day, is opaque and unspecific, but it's not apparent that more time would have helped. The real flaw is that it generally records only matters on which there was majority agreement, omitting any true notes of conflict. Although the report rightly touts the presence of women at the synod—calling for the Church to “adopt a more decisive commitment to understand and accompany women from a pastoral and sacramental point of view”—there isn't a word about the prospect of ordaining women to the priesthood (only a question about how the Church can “include more women in existing roles and ministries”), and the question of ordaining women as deacons (a role involving both a presence at the altar and leadership in the community) is answered with a gesture toward “deeper study.” The word “divorce” never appears (just “complicated marital situations”), nor do the terms “homosexual,” “gay,” or “LGBTQ” (just matters of “identity and sexuality”), with the explanation that “sometimes the anthropological categories we have developed are not able to grasp the complexity of the elements emerging from experience or knowledge in the sciences and require greater precision and further study.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Female participants I spoke with felt that the report's avoidance of hot-button issues made sense, because it foregrounded the process of fostering a “synodal” Church in which people can “walk together” despite their differences. That's an appealing idea, but it also calls to mind the Vatican's long-established practices of silence or circumlocution on vexed topics, a stress on outward unity over internal criticism, and a perspective distant from life as it is actually lived. It also leaves out that, no matter how many women take part in proceedings like the synod, the exercise of Church authority is largely reserved for the ordained—that is, for men.

;
;
;

;The combination of a conflict-averse summary report and a restriction on further comment makes it unlikely that the synodal process will renew the Church prior to next year's session, much less help ordinary Catholics face conflicts in their lives. Perhaps this should be no surprise, though, because the question of what a synod ought to do has been unclear for sixty years.

;

;Shortly after Pope John XXIII was elected, in 1958, he decided to call for a grand ecumenical council, hoping to renew Catholicism through an encounter with modernity. First, in 1960, he convened a one-week Synod of Bishops, in Rome, where he began to set out the upcoming Second Vatican Council's agenda. Vatican II, held in four autumnal sessions beginning in October, 1962, defied all expectations, changing the Church's liturgy (from Latin to local languages, and from a rite performed by the priest on behalf of the people to one “celebrated” by the priest with them), its stance toward other faiths (Jews, long calumniated as descendants of those who had killed Jesus, were recognized as bearers of the “spiritual patrimony” shared by Christianity, and looked to as partners in “fraternal dialogues”), and its approach to democracy and nuclear war. And it gave new emphasis to the understanding of the Pope as the bishop of Rome—not so much an absolute ruler as a kind of first among equals.

;

;Vatican II dealt at length with synods and synodality. Paul VI, elected Pope after John's death, in 1963, envisioned the synod as a crucial element of the post-Vatican II Church, both in Rome and regionally. The approach soon thrived in Latin America, where bishops in Medellín, Colombia, in 1968, sought to apply Vatican II's reforms in the region: controversially, they affirmed support for the liberation of the region's poor, recognized lay-organized “base communities” (which critics called Marxist cells), and deemed the élites' grip on wealth and power as “institutionalized violence.” But such initiatives were largely suppressed after John Paul II took office, in 1978. In the Polish Pope's world view, anti-Communism and traditionalism were inextricably combined; for him, renewal had spread out of control, and the regional synods were part of the problem. To reduce their role, paradoxically, he called for a synod on the topic of Vatican II which would reassert traditionalist Catholicism, rooted in papal authority.

;

;That synod, held in Rome in 1985, had profound consequences over the next thirty years. National churches were made subservient to Rome, and theologians subject to supervision by bishops and Vatican officials. Contested issues—contraception, in-vitro fertilization, the ordination of women and married men, homosexuality—were considered closed to further discussion. The bishops and archbishops appointed by John Paul and his successor, Benedict XVI, took on the role of traditionalist culture warriors. Prominent Catholics who held stances different from theirs were derided as heretics or seen as captive to a “dictatorship of relativism.”

;

;Francis has spent his pontificate trying to dig the Church out from the effects of the 1985 synod. (“He is hitting the reset button on synodality,” Myriam Wijlens, a Dutch theologian and canon lawyer, told me.) So the fact that a synod which he himself called, shaped, and joined evidently didn't begin to bring about any recognizable changes (through the “development of doctrine,” as it's referred to) is discouraging to many Catholics. Sure, involving lots of women in a Vatican synod is a giant step forward. But the new approach presumes that women broadly will be willing to join the Church or stick with it while waiting for a far-off day when their descendants will be allowed to assume full leadership roles. And the refusal of a “listening” Church even to acknowledge hard questions and the discord they involve suggests that Francis's openness to change may have turned out to be no match for the conflict-suppressing forces of the Vatican. At this point, is the Church that Francis leads being over-managed by his subordinates, or under-managed by the Pope himself? That seems to be a question that requires further study. ♦

;Talia Chetrit wants you to know that her partner, Denis, doesn't normally bottle-feed their son while wearing a Gucci bondage harness. Nevertheless, she understands the confusion. Chetrit is a photographer who has often made herself and her family the subjects of her work, which would seemingly situate her in a lineage of diaristic artists such as ;Sally Mann; and ;Elinor Carucci;. But she told me recently, when I visited her studio, in upstate New York, that she considers all of her work “pure fiction.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Chetrit, whose first solo museum show in the United States is now on view at the Wadsworth Atheneum, in Hartford, Connecticut, has had what appears at first glance to be a peripatetic career in photography. In addition to her self-portraits and pictures of her family, she has done moody, telephoto street photographs, optically tricky still-lifes, and slick fashion shoots. She has even dived into heady conceptual waters, exhibiting photos that she made in high school, which take on poignant layers of meaning in retrospect. Ultimately, however, her disparate work is part of a unified quest to pick apart and play with photographic conventions and, by extension, to poke holes in our expectations of what an image can reveal or hide.

;;;;

;Born and raised in Washington, DC, Chetrit recalls that she was “out of the womb calling myself an artist.” She started making pictures as a teen-ager, setting up a darkroom in her parents' laundry room and taking over a custodial closet at her high school. But she claims, in characteristically elusive fashion, that she was “never interested in other people's photography.” It was only later, while studying at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, that she came to the conclusion that her ideas were better suited to the medium. The pictures that she made in high school, and later repurposed, were by no means virtuosic. They were, for the most part, exactly what you would expect. There is a pouty self-portrait in a short tennis skirt that radiates both childish petulance and budding sexual awareness. In her photographs of friends, some subjects practically vibrate with adolescent awkwardness, and others melodramatically perform their angst. A nude portrait of two female friends strikes a tenuous balance between discomfort and half-understood sensuality. Seen now, the power and the charm of this early work spring directly from its guilelessness. Other photographers have attempted to capture the essence of girlhood directly—Mann, for instance, in her stunning, controversial series “Immediate Family,” or Justine Kurland in her more allegorical, cinematic “;Girl Pictures;.” But Chetrit's novel act of self-appropriation delivers truths by way of her younger self's ham-fisted attempt to conceal them.

;;;;

;Another group of images from those days presaged Chetrit's interest in photographic fiction. In them, her friends play dead, the victims of made-up murders that look simultaneously grisly and unconvincing. (In one, a victim is pictured slumped against a door, her bloodied hand resting on a piece of paper so as not to dirty the floor.) The pictures make me think of ;Weegee;'s sensationalized crime-scene photos, and of our culture's ghoulish obsession with true crime. I think of the horrors of school shootings, and the pictures of their aftermath that never reach the public eye. I think of the images of children killed in warfare, pushed onto our social-media feeds. For a teen-age Chetrit, however, the constructed scenes were mostly a way to make pictures that weren't boring. She told me, “ I had this breakthrough moment in high school where I was, like, 'Oh, I don't need to wait until my life becomes interesting.' ”

;;;;

;Chetrit has never let go of the idea that photography can be used to create an illusory world outside of our humdrum day-to-day. In her mature pictures, she almost seems to be daring you to believe that she is telling the truth. Some of them, like an image on view at the Wadsworth of Chetrit holding her son to her chest immediately after giving birth, have the unmistakable flavor of intimacy. They are what you might expect from a photographer who is intent on bringing the viewer close and getting “real.” But others, like her series of deadpan “bottomless” self-portraits, for which she poses for the camera nude from the waist down, or a pair of lighthearted pictures of her and Denis having sex in a bucolic field that are intruded upon by the sinuous black line of the camera's cable release, feel more like a burlesque of intimacy. Chetrit seems to be mocking our desire for self-exposure without actually divulging much. She told me that she started making her sex pictures soon after she and Denis began dating, as a kind of “test” to see if he would be “willing to be there in my work.” She went on, “That wasn't our sex life. That was our sex life with a camera, and what the camera did to our sex life and our relationship at the time.”

;;;;

;Chetrit's editorial work has allowed her to play around with designer clothing, like that Gucci harness, which she gets on loan from various stylist friends and collaborators. She takes obvious pleasure in dressing Denis in an array of high-end womenswear and edgy, bondage-inspired kit, and in the provocative strangeness of, say, juxtaposing the legs of her infant son with a pair of glossy, thigh-high stiletto boots. For a series of photographs, she invited the makeup artist and Andy Warhol associate Corey Tippin to do her up in his signature clownish style. In an image, Chetrit appears with a stocking stretched over her garish face, like some perverse mashup of a china doll and a bank robber. You get the sense that she views making a photograph the same way a child views playing dress-up: as a chance to stretch the boundaries of the possible.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;;

;

;

;

;Even if Chetrit considers her work “pure fiction,” her images sometimes betray the eye of a documentarian. A picture of her son, adorably flailing on Denis's chest, with a foot pressed against his father's stubbled chin, is a stirring, unfakeable portrait of family life. In her pictures of Denis, no matter how ludicrous or stagy, it is impossible to conceal that he is her willing, often joyful, accomplice. (She told me that his reaction to her more outlandish requests is always: “What? No! OK”) Similarly, her pictures of her parents exude their supportive gameness, and touchingly expose their affection for each other. Her self-portraits, which stray intentionally into self-objectification, have a sneaking air of defiance, like one she took while pregnant, naked and straddling a mirror with her camera pressed to an eye. Chetrit's photography asks us to reflect on the imaginary worlds that images create. But sometimes, even through the fun-house lens, small truths, like love or self-love, can be glimpsed.

;Since the Hamas attack on Israel on October 7th, and Israel's subsequent bombing and invasion of Gaza, antisemitic incidents have been ;rising; across the world. Governments and civil-society groups in the United States, Europe, Latin America, and Africa have reported a significant increase in attacks against Jewish people and their property. To try to understand these hate crimes, and the historical forces behind antisemitism, I recently spoke by phone with David Feldman, the director of the Birkbeck Institute for the Study of Antisemitism, at Birkbeck College, University of London. During our conversation, which has been edited for length and clarity, we discussed how different ideological strains of antisemitism coexist and overlap, what makes the latest wave of incidents so disturbing, and whether there are dangers in focussing too much on the Middle East when talking about hatred in America.

;

;;We've seen upsurges in antisemitism before. Does this feel similar or different to you?;

;

;From the UK, at least, it feels different, and it feels different in two ways. One is that I think the rise in antisemitic incidents recorded by the police over the last three weeks or so, since the 7th of October, has been more dramatic than anything we've experienced in the past. And also, as you'll know, in recent years we've had—and not just in the UK but in other countries in Europe as well—debates and arguments about how to talk about Israel, the lines between antisemitism and anti-Zionism, and what definitions are helpful. This has been happening since the war in Gaza in 2006. But this war is on a much greater scale, and of course was preceded by a massacre in Israel. Whereas previous instances were chiefly about how we should talk about events going on in Israel-Palestine, the current moment is about responses to dreadful slaughter.

;

;;What are the different definitions of antisemitism that you alluded to, and how have they featured in these prior debates?;

;

;The International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance adopted its definition of antisemitism in 2016. It was an attempt to distinguish antisemitism from legitimate criticism of Israel—although it spoke about other things, that is what was at its core. I would argue that in its design it narrowed the possibilities for speech. It's a rather unclear and complicated document. It says that context is important, but it has often been invoked by people in debate to accuse others of antisemitism without reference to context. But it was widely adopted. [;The IHRA definition states that “antisemitism is a certain perception of Jews, which may be expressed as hatred toward Jews.” Seven of the eleven examples given make reference to Israel.;]

;

;Then, in 2019, a group of people, myself included, began working on what became the Jerusalem Declaration on Antisemitism, which was a response in many ways to the IHRA definition. The Jerusalem Declaration sought to be clear that anything which denied Jews' individual or collective rights was antisemitic, and identified narratives and stereotypes which are antisemitic, and which are sometimes invoked in the context of discourse in Israel-Palestine. However, it tried to be much more clear about distinguishing what was antisemitic and what were legitimate criticisms of Israel and claims made in the cause of justice for Palestinians.

;
;
;

;;The background to our conversation is what happened on October 7th, and Israel's response to it. On a basic level of cause and effect, some of these incidents would not have happened without the bombing of Gaza. That being said, I do not want to excuse people committing hate crimes by tracing it back to a cause. After 9/11, there were a lot of people in America who committed hate crimes against Muslims, but I don't want to blame Osama bin Laden for, say, someone in Wisconsin burning down a mosque.;

;

;No one makes anyone act in an antisemitic way. There's a difference between comprehending the circumstances in which people act and which lead them to act in particular ways and excusing hate crimes, and I would simply draw the line there. I do think that one of the problems in the current debate, whether it's over hate crimes outside of Israel or in responses to what happened on the 7th of October, is that some people who seek to explain are then accused of condoning. And, of course, that is what happened to the Secretary-General of the United Nations, in which he both condemned Hamas's actions but said that those actions did not emerge from a vacuum. So there's a difference between trying to talk about cause and effect and excusing an action.

;

;;Hamas arose in a political context of a long-term conflict between Israelis and Palestinians. There's definitely a context for Hamas, even if we're horrified by the way they behave. I don't know what the context is for someone yelling slurs at British Jews in London.;

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;I think that the issue we reach here is the way in which events in Israel and Palestine reverberate and divide people beyond Israel and Palestine. So obviously, as you will know, Jews in the UK and elsewhere don't speak with one voice on this, but mainstream Jewish institutions have lined up quite solidly behind Israel's actions and policies since the 7th of October. So there is a way in which mainstream Jews in the diaspora identify with Israel and are then identified by others with Israel, which I think is simply providing a context in which Jewish buildings are attacked.

;
;
;

;Something awful just happened, which is that the word “Gaza” was daubed in red paint outside the Wiener Holocaust Library, which is a library and archive dedicated to the study of the Holocaust. There's no way in which that is a legitimate action, but clearly whoever was performing that action identified the building as one associated with Jews, and he associated Jews with the support for the State of Israel. This is me speaking, if you like, as an academic. And in that context, it seems to me that either we give up or we try to understand why people are acting the way they're acting. Otherwise, the humanities are not really serving a useful purpose.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;I'm just not sure the type of people who commit hate crimes really care that mainstream Jewish organizations do or do not line up with Israel. I feel like hate crimes may be happening separately from that context, that those may be two trains running on parallel tracks, but they're not actually connected.;

;

;Yeah.

;

;;Especially with something like antisemitism or any sort of bigotry, I do wonder if looking at proximate causes misses something.;

;
;
;

;Yeah. In a sense, the answer to your question is that we don't know. But, in some ways, I suggest the reverse of what you said is likely to be the case. In normal times, there are a good deal of hate crimes which take place, and which are akin to hooliganism. Someone sees a person looking visibly Jewish in the street and they pick on them. This is a known phenomenon. But if one looks at the example that I just gave of someone daubing “Gaza” on the wall of a library and archive dedicated to the Holocaust, if one looks at people throwing Molotov cocktails at a synagogue, for example, then I think one does need to look at the immediate context.

;

;;It's telling when people choose to focus on root causes and when they don't, and it often shows where their sympathies lie.;

;

;Sure, I can understand that. And it's certainly very important to use the same criteria and approaches for all hate crimes across the board. One wouldn't want to try to explain hate crimes against Jews in the ways that we've been discussing but not do so for hate crimes against the other groups. And I agree with you that on some occasions people pick and choose.

;

;But hate crimes aren't really what I do and what I think about, as perhaps is a bit obvious. Fundamentally, I'm a historian, and I can place what we're thinking about today in terms of antisemitism in some sort of historical context. I'm not particularly comfortable with the focus on the causality of hate crimes. That's not because it's not a set of legitimate questions; they are, and I think you are raising important issues, but it's not really what I do.

;

;Going back to the different definitions of antisemitism, and a way of putting the present moment in some sort of context—I think Jews arguing over what is and what is not antisemitism is not new, and what Jews mean by antisemitism is something which has changed over time. These debates are the latest iteration of a long history, which goes back to when the word antisemitism came into common usage, which was in the eighteen-eighties.

;

;When it first came into common usage, certainly in Western Europe, it had a much more restricted meaning than it's come to have since. Then, the antisemitic movement was a real German movement, which called itself the Anti-Semitic League. And they brought into question civil equality for Jews. Antisemitism was widely understood to be about that. It was about the idea that Jews should not enjoy equality with other subjects.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Now, one of the extraordinary consequences is that the pogroms in Russia were not spoken of as antisemitic in the West. They were barbaric, they were medieval, they were uncivilized. But because Jews in Russia did not have rights to be taken away from them, those pogroms didn't fit the meaning of antisemitism. The point of talking about that is to say that the meaning of antisemitism has changed over time, and our recent debates are just the latest stage in a long history.

;

;;So much of it today is based on Israel, which is not to say that there wouldn't still be antisemites if there were no Israel. Do you see the post-1948 period as its own period of antisemitism?;

;
;
;

;OK, so that's a really big question.

;

;;You have thirty seconds to answer it.;

;

;I'll do it in the form of a haiku. There are different dimensions to this question. I have written about antisemitism as a reservoir in the culture, something there to be drawn on. And this is a reservoir which has built up over centuries, even over millennia. There are three key elements in this: one is the idea that Judaism has been superseded by Christianity (the notion that Jews have a particularistic and narrow morality is one consequence of that idea); second, the idea that Jews are forever conspiratorial and up to something against the common good; and, third, the connection of Jews with money. These ideas have been repurposed over centuries in multiple political contexts. And we see them repurposed in some of the antisemitic attacks on Israel.

;

;One thing shown by multiple opinion surveys in the United States, Germany, and in the UK and elsewhere, is that the percentage of committed ideological antisemites is relatively small, but the diffusion of negative stereotypes and narratives about Jews through the culture is much higher and much wider. At certain moments, people draw on these, especially at political flash points when these ideas appear to be useful, and when they appear to explain something. Yes, there are antisemites, sort of ideologically committed individuals and groups who have an antisemitic world view, but much more commonplace are individuals who draw on the well of antisemitism within the culture. And that's what we see in antisemitism around Israel.

;

;;Today, there is what I think people would perceive as right-wing antisemitism that you see from Donald Trump's online followers, and whomever else. There's left-wing antisemitism, too. And then you have the antisemitism of certain groups in the Middle East, such as Hamas, which I think in an American political context are associated more with the left, but if you actually look at their ideas about, say, gay people, they appear right-wing. Do you think of these different strands of antisemitism as very distinct in some way?;

;

;I would want to think about them as being distinct. You have distinct political traditions which draw on a common culture. There is a tradition of writing about antisemitism which simply emphasizes these long continuities. And I think that as a historian, that doesn't help one understand the particular instances when they arise, and they also can lead one to misunderstand the present moment.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;For example, look at the very understandable description of the events of the massacre of the 7th of October as a pogrom. It's easy to understand why people draw on Jewish collective memory to describe these events. However, pogroms in Russia and later in Poland took place where Jews were a racialized minority, relatively powerless, vulnerable, and the violence meted out against them was an attempt to put them in their place. The violence meted out against the Israelis was awful. But calling them pogroms does not see the very different context in which they took place, in a state in which Jews are a majority, in which they have state power. In those terms, if one did want to speak about pogroms, one would be looking at the events in the West Bank in ;Huwara; earlier this year.

;

;;Maybe this gets to something that's been complicated about the current rise in antisemitism. After October 7th, all the major Western powers have lined up pretty solidly behind Israel, with the political support for the Jewish people and the Jewish state being incredibly strong. That is one reason that people have trouble grasping the extent of antisemitism. They say, “You've got people of both political parties in America supporting Jews, supporting Israel,” and so on and so forth.;

;
;
;

;It's not only that the Western powers have lined up solidly behind Israel—it's that Western powers in their internal policies are very clear about combating antisemitism. Biden produced his strategic plan to combat antisemitism. In the UK, the government helps fund security of buildings which house Jewish institutions. It's helping fund a Holocaust memorial project next to the Houses of Parliament. The German government is very strong in seeking to prevent any recurrence of antisemitism in German society.

;

;This, historically, is unprecedented. If one goes back to the interwar years, governments in Europe were either explicitly hostile to Jews or largely indifferent to them as they faced persecution. One of the things which this points to are the ways in which mainstream Jewish communities in the United States and in Europe have very often made alliances with governments, and with those in power. And it's not that there are no alliances with other racialized minorities, but these have often suffered and frayed. And the vertical alliances, which Jews have made, in some ways leave them vulnerable to radical groups who sympathize with the Palestinians and who have little sympathy either with Israel or with its supporters. These vertical alliances offer some rewards and some safety to Jewish people outside of Israel, but they also bring dangers.

;

;;Why does it bring danger necessarily to be protected?;

;

;It brings danger if people think that Jews are being protected in ways that the other groups are not. And it brings danger because it angers people who are against the state or against the system, however they conceive it. That can be and sometimes is understood by people on the left in conspiratorial ways. And many people who are engaged in the movement for Palestinian rights are also engaged in wider political activities around race and social justice. Although there are points of solidarity between Jews and other racialized minorities, it's also the case that the impact of Israel-Palestine has been to make those other solidarities harder and harder to build.

;

;;It feels a little bit like a Catch-22 to suggest that Jews in the twentieth century faced widespread antisemitism, faced the Holocaust, and then in response sought political alliances, and now they're disliked for doing that. I guess my concern about focussing on any stated cause of antisemitism is it seems a little bit like you are damned if you do and damned if you don't.;

;

;This is not about causality. It's about thinking through how a dynamic arises. People are making political choices. And alliances are made and alliances are broken. It's trying to understand that dynamic. It's not trying to say, “Well, these vertical alliances are a cause of antisemitism,” but I am saying that these vertical alliances in a time of heightened anti-racist mobilization across society reveal the different strategies being taken by Jews and by other racialized minorities. That speaks to your question about the paradox of the position of Jews in many countries, because they are fearful, and at the present moment antisemitic incidents are rising dramatically. What I've been trying to talk about is how to understand this. ♦

;上周，以色列的一次空袭杀死了电视记者穆罕默德·阿布·哈塔布 (Mohammed Abu Hatab) 以及他的十一位家人在加沙南部的家中。据保护记者委员会称，他是在当前冲突中确认死亡的第三十六位媒体成员。这个数字稳步上升。绝大多数是当地加沙人，他们试图在持续的轰炸中掩盖这场危机。直到最近，还没有新的外国记者或独立组织被允许见证正在发生的事情。

;

;自 10 月初以来，我一直试图从远处捕捉加沙生活的片段，主要是通过 WhatsApp 与那里的人和巴勒斯坦裔美国人。似乎每个人都认识死去的人。

;

;Hossin Shaqur 是一位住在加利福尼亚州圣巴巴拉的保险经纪人，在家人流离失所后，他出生在加沙北部的贾巴利亚难民营。 1948 年，他来自一个村庄，现在是以色列南部的一部分。 1967 年，全家人的一些人搬到了卡塔尔，最终搬到了美国，但他的妹妹、侄女和侄子、表兄弟姐妹以及叔叔阿姨仍然留在贾巴利亚。侯辛告诉我，自以色列的轰炸行动开始以来，他已经证实，他的近七十名亲属已被杀害。他母亲家居住的街区被夷为平地。他最后听到的消息是，他的妹妹还活着。 “但我不知道她现在是否还活着，”他在电话里告诉我。 “我们都沉迷于电视。你看了几个小时的新闻，做了一些事情，然后你回来，新的事情发生了。它会重演。”

;

;爆炸开始几天后，许多加沙人认为他们可能会在南部找到安全。 Noor Harazeen, a young journalist based in Gaza City, left her home and travelled with her husband and their children to Deir al-Balah, in the middle of the Strip.当努尔从那里给我发消息时，她已经超过二十四小时没有喝水了。几乎没有饮用水源；她和她的家人一直靠果汁维持生计。

;

;以色列对加沙发动战争后不久，为了回应哈马斯 10 月 7 日的袭击，军用飞机在北部（包括加沙城）投放传单，警告居民——大约一百万人——需要疏散。家人努力决定该怎么做。几乎紧接着，加沙城一条被认为是“安全路线”的道路遭到空袭，据报道造成 70 人死亡。 （哈马斯指责以色列对这次袭击负责，但以色列国防军否认对此负责。）

;

;即使在南部，爆炸事件也似乎是随机的。第一周的一个下午晚些时候，医学院三年级学生阿拉·扎赫·艾哈迈德 (Alaa Zaher Ahmed) 正在汗尤尼斯的房间里设计一张宣传乳腺癌意识的海报。 “突然间，一切都开始摇晃，我发现自己身处黑暗之中，”她通过语音告诉我。 “什么也看不见。”首先，她发现自己还有呼吸，然后发现一只手无法动弹，然后头很痛。她摸了摸，指尖感觉到了“粘稠的液体”。 Blood.阿拉试图移动，但她的腿被压住了，她感觉不到它们。在她的上方是某种神秘、沉重、具体的东西。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;她猜测，可能已经过了十分钟，然后她听到了似乎越来越大的低沉声音。阿拉开始尖叫并敲击她上方的混凝土。一位邻居将她从废墟中救了出来。救援队和亲属继续在残骸中挖掘。几个小时后，他们发现了她的大部分家人：她的母亲、兄弟和侄子，全都死了。她告诉我，她的三层楼房子“像饼干一样倒塌了”。在塌陷的遗迹中，仅有的几件还能辨认的东西——床垫、沙发、粉红色的布料——都被灰尘覆盖了。

;

;联合国估计，自战争以来，加沙一半以上的人口已经流离失所。战争的开始。人们被分散到原来的难民营、不同城市的朋友或亲戚家、学校或医院。阿德南·萨瓦达 (Adnan Sawada) 的家人就是其中之一。阿德南，五十五岁，经营一家运输公司，住在马里兰州。他的家人住在加沙城北部的谢赫拉德万，在传单撒下后决定搬家。他们带了一张床垫、一些衣服、孩子们的玩具和食物，最后像努尔一样，来到了代尔巴拉赫。

;

;阿德南已经十三年没有见过他的任何兄弟姐妹了。几个月前，他通过电话与他的大哥沙班交谈。沙班兴奋得头晕目眩。他的儿子要结婚了，很快他就会有一个孙子了。 “我老了，很享受生活。”阿德南记得他说过。

;
;
;

;阿德南所知道的，转达给他的其侄子的说法是这样的：10月16日下午，沙班和另一个兄弟在屋外谈话。哥哥进去了。突然，一声巨响，一切都颤抖起来。当弟弟出来时，他发现沙班倒在地上，浑身是血，一条腿没了。沙班被紧急送往医院，但当医生看到他时，他已经死亡。 “显然，他死于失血过多，”阿德南告诉我，“但全部原因都是炸弹。”

;
;
;

;漫长的等待就诊时间已经变得司空见惯。然后。加沙城的希法医院是加沙地带最大的医院，因受伤的男女、儿童和婴儿的涌入而不堪重负。塔尼姆·哈马德 (Tarneem Hammad) 是一位驻加沙的作家，与人道主义援助团体合作，他告诉我，医生将这家医院描述为“屠宰场”。有太多的死者到达，或者无法获救。由于物资短缺，一些人在没有麻醉的情况下被切割和缝合。

;

;“记者们睡在医院的地板上，”努尔在 10 月 17 日早上告诉我。 “至少比其他地方更安全。”这种计算很快就发生了变化。当天晚些时候，同样位于加沙城的阿赫利阿拉伯医院发生爆炸，造成约一百人死亡；原因尚不清楚，但有证据表明是巴勒斯坦激进组织发射的火箭。最近，加沙的一位医生给我发了一段视频，视频中以色列对圣城医院附近发动袭击，烟雾腾腾。上周，以色列袭击了希法医院入口附近。 （以色列国防军发言人表示，它将“在必要时打击哈马斯。”）

;努尔到达代尔巴拉赫后不久，我又收到了她的来信。 “你可以睡着，永远不会醒来，”她告诉我。 “你可以睡觉，醒来时听到家人被杀的消息。 No one is safe if he is Gazan or a foreigner.如果一个人是公民或武装分子，那么没有人是安全的。如果他是一名医生、记者，那么没有人是安全的。”

;

;随着时间的推移，一些最初撤离的加沙人决定返回家园。炸弹也落在那些在南方寻求庇护的人身上。 The Gaza Strip is only a hundred and forty square miles;人在哪里似乎并不重要。塔尼姆告诉我，她和她的家人做出了留在原地的“艰难决定”。 “加沙现在的计算是，要么你已经被轰炸，要么你只是在等待被轰炸，”她在语音留言中说。 “因此，如果我要在被轰炸前度过最后的日子，我只想待在家里，和家人在一起。”

;

;四个星期前，居住在芝加哥郊外的医学研究员 Nabil Alshurafa 在他的母亲内拉 (Naela) 是一位 66 岁的退休发型师，最近从加利福尼亚州前往加沙北部看望自己的母亲。纳比尔可以听到背景中炸弹的撞击声。当纳比尔还是个孩子的时候，他和他的家人住在科威特，他的父亲是那里的一名医生。纳比尔是美国公民，当时是他家里唯一的人，第一次海湾战争爆发时，美国政府迅速将他们空运回安全地带。他认为现在可能会发生类似的事情。

;

;哈马斯大屠杀后的第二天，内拉乘上一辆出租车向南狂奔，前往拉法过境点，这是加沙与埃及边境的唯一出入口。大门被冲破，她无法出去。两天后，她进行了第二次尝试。她正在排队办理护照盖章，距离埃及只有十分钟路程，突然爆炸震动了边境大门。纳比尔从他叔叔那里听说了爆炸事件，他不知道内拉是否还活着。几个小时后，纳比尔才得知他的母亲安全了。

;

;纳比尔惊慌失措，绝望地填写了一份国务院危机受理表。他最终收到的电子邮件回复建议加沙的美国公民考虑前往拉法。一周后，当我与纳比尔交谈时，他哭了。当以色列多次袭击拉法时，内埃拉和其他约四百名美国公民仍在加沙地带内。近一个月来，没有一个美国人能够离开。 11 月 1 日，随着法律和公众压力的加大，拜登总统宣布将开始疏散美国公民。奈拉就在名单上，第二天，她走进了埃及。她的家人仍然留在加沙。

;

;即使在战争之前，加沙也是世界上最难进出的地方之一。自2002年以色列用推土机推平跑道以来，该机场就再也没有正常运转过。 2006年哈马斯赢得选举后，以色列实施封锁，严重限制人员和货物的流动。加沙 65% 的人生活贫困，大约一半人失业。有经济能力和机会的家庭尽量送至少一名孩子出国学习和工作。叶海亚·阿布哈舍姆 (Yahia Abuhashem) 是一名 34 岁的芝加哥数据科学家，十五年前离开加沙，此后就再也没有见过他的父母或兄弟姐妹。一个兄弟是牙医，另一个兄弟是工程师，一个姐妹是律师助理——他告诉我，他们很幸运能有这样的工作，或者根本没有任何工作。尽管如此，他还是定期从美国寄出数百美元来补充他们的收入。

;
;
;

;Yahia 父母的公寓楼，位于他告诉我，加沙城的 Tel al-Hawa 社区在 2021 年的战争中遭到袭击。 （当时，人权观察和国际特赦组织发现了以色列国防军针对住宅楼的模式。“在某些情况下，当他们居住的建筑物倒塌时，整个家庭都被埋在废墟下，”国际特赦组织写道。）父母花了两年半的时间重新装修重建，今年八月，他们终于搬回了家。最近的轰炸一开始，一家人就再次出发，前往南方：一些人去了汗尤尼斯，一些人去了拉法，一些人去了努塞拉特。 Tel al-Hawa 不久之后就遭到轰炸，几天后又遭到轰炸。

;

;据联合国称，在以色列轰炸的头三周内，加沙 42% 的住房单元被摧毁。突击。这已经是一个陈旧的数字了。很难知道废墟下有多少人，其中有多少人可能还活着。以色列前驻英国大使兼政府顾问马克·雷格夫在接受天空新闻采访时坚称，以色列不会针对民用建筑。 “战争非常非常困难，”他说。当记者向他追问不断增加的平民死亡和住宅建筑时，他回答说：“它们是哈马斯的目标。”

;在最近晚上，我拜访了在华盛顿特区从事通讯工作的多尔格姆·阿布萨利姆 (Dorgham Abusalim)。他于 2006 年离开加沙出国留学，只回过几次。他客厅里的电视调到了半岛电视台阿拉伯语频道。他指着他的笔记本电脑，他告诉我，笔记本电脑通常也会调到其他新闻频道。当我们说话的时候，他的手一直没有离开他旁边座位上的手机。他是几个从地面传递最新信息的聊天组的成员——信息流的传播速度比西方媒体报道的速度略快。即使提前几分钟，也意味着恐慌与解脱、或者恐慌与悲伤之间的时间会更短。

;

;两天前的凌晨 1:30，他的手机响起了“叮叮”声。注意到代尔巴拉赫（Deir al-Balah），他的父母和一个妹妹住在那里。数十人被杀。多尔格姆惊慌失措地给他在加拿大的兄弟打电话，他的兄弟多次拨打他父母的电话号码。多尔格姆也尝试过，但电话没有接通。他花了几个小时滚动浏览收到的每条更新。他放大了熟悉街道的图像，寻找邻居的房子、他的学校或他自己的家的闪光。

;

;最后，大约四点- 三十岁，他哥哥打电话叫他去睡觉：“他们还活着。”

;

;“我起床了，快去睡觉吧。” 10 月 24 日，救援人员塔尼姆 (Tarneem) 在 WhatsApp 上发消息告诉我。那是半夜。 “累了。我;很;累了，”她说。食物很少；她没有喝足够的水。 “我睡不着，我的脑子里整天听到爆炸声。”

;

;当天，记者努尔给我发了一条语音信息。 “事实上，我还活着，”她说道，语气听起来像是惊讶。她还在代尔巴拉赫。 “它可以翻译为枣子之城，”她说，“因为这里种满了枣树。”过去几天袭击事件愈演愈烈，她一直在舒哈达阿克萨医院报道。 “我们看到了太多我们不应该看到的事情，”她说。尸体、伤害、儿童、妇女。 “是的，这真的很难。”

;

;最近加沙部分地区的卫星图像从上方揭示了后果。大多数曾经白色的屋顶都被灰色覆盖了。曾经矗立的建筑群现在看起来就像是污迹。拉斯维加斯大道布满弹坑。上周，以色列国防部长约阿夫·加兰特表示，以色列仅在比曼哈顿还小的加沙城投下了一万多枚炸弹。我从几份报告和与我交谈过的人那里了解到，空气中弥漫着烟雾、灰尘、腐烂尸体和污水的味道。

;

;Yahia 和许多其他巴勒斯坦裔美国人一样，一直在试图联系他在国会的代表请求帮助确保他家人的安全。轰炸开始一周后，他联系了参议员塔米·达克沃斯。他与我分享了他收到的回复信。它的开头是“感谢您就哈马斯针对以色列的可怕恐怖袭击与我联系。我以最强烈的措辞谴责哈马斯自 2023 年 10 月 7 日开始的残酷暴力行为。”

;
;
;

;更多据加沙卫生部称，以色列的报复性袭击已造成一万人死亡。最近，拜登总统表示，他“对巴勒斯坦人使用的数字没有信心”。作为明显的回应，加沙当局公布了两百多页的死者姓名，以及他们的身份证号码、性别和年龄。死亡儿童的数量惊人——截至撰写本文时已有四千多名儿童——促使;联合国儿童基金会;称这种情况为“我们集体良心上日益严重的污点”。

;

;当晚晚些时候10月27日，加沙陷入黑暗。以色列削减电信服务；没有人可以使用互联网或电话。媒体和国际组织宣布与同事失去联系。 All the people I was talking to on WhatsApp stopped responding.

;

;That weekend, Israeli troops pushed into Gaza.据报道，在美国的压力下，近两天后，以色列恢复了通讯线路。 （随后又发生了其他停电。）在地面上与我交谈过的每个人都慢慢开始回复我。接下来的几天里，以色列的炸弹摧毁了胡辛姐姐居住地附近的贾巴利亚难民营的部分地区。塔尼姆发了一条消息，她的声音安静而颤抖。她生病了。她告诉我，当电话线被切断时，邻居们用驴车抬着伤者和死者。自从我们开始交谈以来，她第一次承认，“我不会在感情上处理任何事情。”

;

;就在本文发表之前，纳比尔向我发送了另一条更新：一次空袭杀死了他妻子的叔叔，阿姨，还有他们的三个孩子和三个孙子。 ♦

;;I.发射;

;

;与同时代的其他探险一样，坚韧号的十八世纪航行也有着崇高的目标。我的一百四十英尺战舰试图首次前往南极，这一壮举将为英国带来自豪。但我计划做的远不止这些。在回家的路上，我们会在巴西停留，向那里的人们传授基督教和镜子，然后前往阿根廷拿走那里的锡，然后去塔希提岛亲吻那里的女人。喝了一两杯啤酒后，我什至会吹嘘说，如果时间允许的话，我们会找到失落的城市亚特兰蒂斯。

;

;二十八岁，对于一名船长来说还很年轻。我被描述为身材魁梧，身高五英尺六英寸，声音低沉，眼神锐利。我的名字是 Herbrerm Enrory Howrard Pinkleton，但对于朋友们来说，我只是 Herbrerm EH Pinkleton。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;发布会当天，围观群众络绎不绝。我记得我凝视着我的妻子和孩子，但随后目光越过了他们，转向了我的父亲。亨利·霍拉特里奥·“军阀”·平克尔顿是一位功勋卓著的皇家海军上将，他因仅凭一小群英国船只就击败了西班牙无敌舰队而闻名，另外还因徒手勒死一名西班牙男子而闻名（并非军事行动） ）。当我的手下努力组装备用缆索时，我看到他的目光眯了起来。当时对经验丰富的海员的需求量很大，而我只剩下一群旱鸭子、新手和岸上笨蛋。

;

;我自己没有太多经验，从来没有在技术上担任过船长。船。我曾经当过大副，但那是在去爱尔兰的小艇上。我完全意识到，国王催促我担任这个职位，因为他们厌倦了听到锡有多么好，以及阿根廷有多少锡。我下定决心有一天要带着一艘装满闪闪发光的东西的船回到这个港口，而我的父亲则在一旁看着。

;
;

;;II。 THE SQUALL;

;
;
;

;5 月 2 日中午刚过，坚韧号沾满泥浆的锚船被拖起来并绑在舷墙上，我们出发前往南极，所有的帆都在微风中调整。我凝视着泰晤士河对岸，思考着前方的挑战。尤其是合恩角，那里有可怕的灰胡子（据说海浪至少有八十英尺高），而且我们会在冰上度过严酷的冬天，靠被我们打死的海豹为生。我还想到了我的妻子和七个孩子，他们仍在岸边挥手，想知道他们在我不在的三年里会过得怎么样。

;

;好运并没有伴随着下水。我的大副 Teeshy McGann 告诉我，一场意想不到的风暴正从东方袭来。他建议我们降低帆并等待，甚至可能退回码头。 “不要降帆！”我哭了，声音大得岸上的每个人都能听到。 “让我们给这狂风一拳！”

;
;
;

;毁灭性的狂风一降临到我们身上，我就喊道：“孩子们，迎风而行！” and grabbed the wheel myself.过了一会儿，我改变了主意，喊道：“等等，你们这些白痴，快走开！”这使得船处于一个脆弱的位置，她向下风方向倾斜得如此之大，以致于她的桅杆尖端陷入了水中。我们都紧紧抓住栏杆。甲板下的牲畜被扔来扔去，人们不得不遮住脸，因为凶恶、咬人的猪如雨点般落下。麦甘喊道：“到救生艇上来！”

;

;但我现在比以往任何时候都希望我的船更轻、更快。 “实际上，切断救生艇！”我哭了。 “把所有储存的食物和水都扔到海里。”我为这些命令没有口齿不清而感到自豪。我想知道父亲是否注意到了。没有什么可生气的。

;

;坚韧号继续颠簸，一些人被头朝下扔进甲板上的木制厕所里，窒息而死。这种现象屡见不鲜，以至于成了“我忙得头埋粪、腿乱踢”这句话的由来。

;

;我决定制作。我的船要么可以返回码头并被修理，而我则在父亲和越来越多的人群面前遭受羞辱。或者我们可以继续前往南极和阿根廷，那里有闪亮的锡，还有塔希提岛的女人，她们的嘴唇不是英国人的。对我来说，没有决定。 ♦

;众所周知，电影行业不稳定，对于任何敢于思考的公司来说，这条道路尤其危险电影既是一门艺术，也是一门商业。 So it's a cause for celebration that ;Zeitgeist Films;, one of the most eminent art-house film distributors, has just reached its thirty-fifth anniversary, and Metrograph is aptly celebrating with ;a monthlong series; of in-theatre and online offerings, spotlighting some of Zeitgeist's most significant releases. Even before I was a critic, when I paid little attention to the business side of film, I've been honoring Zeitgeist from afar. As it happens, the company was co-founded by a friend of mine from high school, Emily Russo, together with Nancy Gerstman, and I've always taken special vicarious pleasure in the company's successes releasing independent and international films that might otherwise have gone entirely unseen in the United States.

;

;Zeitgeist's influential releases are too numerous and varied to do justice to in a brief column. One could point to its release of ;Todd Haynes;'s first feature, “Poison,” from 1991, which not only put that director on the map but helped launch the New Queer Cinema movement. Or one could note its line of ingenious docu-fictions, including Tony Buba's “;Lightning Over Braddock,;” ;Agnès Varda;'s “The Gleaners and I,” and Yvonne Rainer's “;Privilege;.” Or one could recall that, with Jia Zhangke's “The World,” Zeitgeist distributed one of the best films of the twenty-first century. But, in my view, no achievement has been greater than the vital role the company has played in bringing to the attention of American viewers one of the greatest of all filmmakers, ;Abbas Kiarostami;, with the release of the 1997 film “Taste of Cherry” (which, now, is streaming on the Criterion Channel and Max).

;

;Contrary to what you may have heard, the nineteen-nineties were a terrible time to be releasing independent and international films. The decade's reputation as a boom time for American independents holds true mostly for Hollywood-proximate, commercially oriented independent films exemplified by “;Reservoir Dogs;.” More artistically ambitious fare—such as Wendell B. Harris, Jr.,'s “;Chameleon Street;,” Zeinabu irene Davis's “;Compensation;,” and Eric Mendelsohn's “Judy Berlin”—went either unreleased or severely underreleased. Moreover, many of the best international films of the decade, too, remained undistributed; shockingly, Philippe Collin's “;The Last Days of Immanuel Kant;” and even ;Jean-Luc Godard;'s “Nouvelle Vague” (starring Alain Delon!) are ;still; unreleased here.

;

;Thirty years ago, the business of independent film distribution looked very different from the way it does now. Today, the pipeline from the New York Film Festival to commercial release is wide open, and the flow is fast, but back then it was more of a dribble. Today, social media creates buzz quickly and spreads critical enthusiasm at the speed of light; back then, online life was mainly e-mail—which, in the film world, mostly amounted to cinephiles being able to privately gripe slightly faster than they previously had. Kiarostami's films were emerging in that inhospitable environment, and it is hard to remember, given his now-undisputed eminence, just how long his career languished in the shadows.

;

;Born in 1940, Kiarostami had been making films since 1970 and made his first feature in 1973. As a reader of ;Cahiers du Cinéma;, I'd been aware of his work since around 1990. The movie that served as his first breakout was the 1987 drama “Where Is the Friend's House?”; I also recall reading about his 1989 documentary “Homework”; his first widely acclaimed international masterwork was the 1990 docu-fiction “Close-Up,” which wasn't released here until 1999. The New York Film Festival showed his feature “And Life Goes On” in 1992 and “Through the Olive Trees” in 1994. By the mid-nineties, having seen one or two of his films, I was certain that Kiarostami was one of the most original, conceptually daring, and aesthetically exquisite filmmakers working, and I was dismayed that his films had no presence in the American market. “Through the Olive Trees” was first acquired for theatrical release in the US, but it was ill-served by the company that acquired it, Miramax. The movie must have looked like a good bet for art-house popularity: notwithstanding some metafictional maneuvers, it's a wistful and warmly comic romance. But it seems Miramax got cold feet. It gave the film a nearly unadvertised, pro-forma release in a single obscure theatre, in February, 1995; it went on to keep the film off the home-video market for an unseemly while.

;

;A few weeks before that fiasco of a release, I was in Paris, and, in the role of an unofficial emissary from a small (now defunct) US distributor, I paid a visit to the sales agent for Kiarostami's earlier films. The distribution company was hoping to release one of Kiarostami's films, but the agency informed me that a substantial advance would be required, and the company didn't have the budget for it, so that was that. I tell this story to indicate that the stakes for Zeitgeist were major when it acquired “Taste of Cherry,” in 1997. The film won the biggest prize, the Palme d'Or, at that year's Cannes Film Festival, and the distributor picked up the rights less than a week before its US première at the New York Film Festival; with such a high profile, the film doubtless placed weighty demands on Zeitgeist—all the more so because of the nature and subject of the film.

;
;
;

;“Taste of Cherry” tells the story of a middle-aged man named Mr. Badii (Homayoun Ershadi), who drives in and around Tehran and picks up a series of passengers in the hope that one will take a quick job he is offering. He's planning to lie down in a remote ditch in the nearby countryside that night and take an overdose of sleeping pills, and he wants to hire someone to come by in the morning to check on him. If he's alive, they can help him out of the ditch; if not, they can cover his corpse with shovelfuls of dirt. Badii never discloses his motives, but he is clearly arranging for his putative suicide to be undetectable if it's unsuccessful, and therefore he requires the services of a stranger. He's willing to pay lavishly, offering a sum that it would take a manual laborer six months to earn.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Almost all of the film's action takes place in or near Badii's car, and most of the action is dialogue—extended scenes of discussion, in the car, in a hilly rural area outside the city. Badii attempts to persuade, in succession, three passengers to do the job. One is a young draftee in the Iranian Army; one is a seminary student; the third is an older man who works as a taxidermist at a natural-history museum. There's something cagey and manipulative, yet quietly desperate, about Badii's manner as he offers major money for a job that he refuses to describe up front. His webs of persuasion are elaborately spun—and part of his spinning is his insinuating curiosity about his interlocutors' lives, his eliciting of their stories of need.

;

;In other words, Badii is something of a reporter, and the people he meets have troubles of their own: the soldier is a Kurd who has felt the effects of the Iran-Iraq War in his rural home town; the seminarian is an Afghan who elected to leave his war-ravaged country; the taxidermist has a sick child in need of expensive treatments. Of course, it's Kiarostami who's the quasi-documentarian, not just in his construction of the inquisitive story but also in his filming of it, starting with his view of the barren, sandy, and forbidding rural zone where the action takes place. “Taste of Cherry” is something of his version of “Two or Three Things I Know About Her,” a story of transformative industrialization and modernization that entails new forms of isolation, frustration, and despair. Kiarostami's filming has a documentary-like attentiveness—to landscapes and faces, to situations and ideas—that matches the drama's incremental, investigative, observational poise.

;

;Yet beneath its surfaces lurks radical wildness and radical irony. For starters, suicide isn't just taboo, it's a violation of Islamic law (the seminarian himself says so), and, as a result, “Taste of Cherry” was not only banned from screening in Iran but was nearly banned from export (and therefore from Cannes). Thus it's a tale of explicit defiance, an appeal to another authority that subsumes both civic and religious ones. In effect, it's a movie of moral and bodily autonomy, of the ultimate freedom to be or not to be—a vision of suicide as freedom that picks up where André Malraux and the existentialists left off. And, at the same time, this vision of freedom involves not control but a renunciation of control, a submission to the existential flip of the coin, to the random question of whether the overdose will work. With that undercurrent of ironic uncertainty and decisive indecision, “Taste of Cherry” morphs into a film in a strange category: it's a comedy of suicide, akin to the last film that Jerry Lewis directed, “;Cracking Up;.” One example of its outrageously macabre humor involves a moment of distraction while Badii is driving on a narrow road bordering a sheer sand cliff: just as he's about to go accidentally careening down, his tire gets stuck in the sand. (The sequence thematically rhymes with ;one in Lewis's film;.)

;

;Even the title turns out to be ironic. It suggests the basic and sensual pleasures, the lode of memories that give life meaning and pull a person back into daily doings with a kind of gravitational force. Yet the fondest memory that Badii summons is anything but a bowl of cherries: he remembers his military service, an activity that he specifically describes as requiring a readiness to kill. For that matter, there's another wild paradox in “Taste of Cherry”—its ending is no spoiler. I won't say what becomes of Badii, but, in any case, that's not the ending; rather, Kiarostami leaps outside the frame of the action to conclude with some lo-fi video of the crew shooting the film, of the director calling out to a troop of marching soldiers to get back into position for another take. He ends with a seemingly infinite regress of the reality of the simulation of the reality of the officially sanctioned and mandated, state-approved and religion-blessed power of the dealing of death.

;

;On its release in 1998, “Taste of Cherry” made a mere three hundred thousand dollars in theatrical box-office. But it was named Best Foreign Language Film of the year by the National Society of Film Critics, was a runner-up in that category for the ;New York Film Critics Circle;, and placed fourth (just ahead of “;Goodfellas;”) in the ;;Village Voice; poll; of the best films of the decade. In short, Kiarostami, from then on until the end of his career—he died in 2016—could no longer be denied. “Close-Up” got a belated release in 1999; his 1999 film “The Wind Will Carry Us” was released here promptly the following year. His work has been a mainstay of the American art-house scene, and a prime reference for American critics and filmmakers, ever since. Zeitgeist may not have made a mint releasing it, but the company made history. ♦

;Just after 10 ;AM; on Monday morning, Donald Trump was sworn in at ;his civil trial;, where he has already been found guilty of fraudulently inflating the value of his assets, and where the court is now considering other charges and penalties, which could include a fine of up to two hundred and fifty million dollars and a permanent ban on him running businesses in New York. As sunlight streamed into the packed courtroom, Trump looked the same way he always does: hefty, unnaturally tanned, and ready to do battle.

;

;Kevin Wallace, a lawyer from the New York attorney general's office, started off the questioning gently, but it didn't take long for Trump to go off track and start making political speeches. He complained about prosecutors—“all Democrats, all Trump haters”—who he said were coming at him from “fifteen different directions. 。 。 。 weaponization, they call it.” Wallace tried to guide him back to the issue at hand: the annual Statements of Financial Condition, put together by the Trump Organization, that included the inflated asset values that Judge Arthur F. Engoron, who is presiding over the case, has already ruled fraudulent. Trump sought to downplay the significance of the statements, saying that neither he nor the banks that lent him money paid very much attention to them.

;

;The charges against Trump claim that the Trump Organization used fraudulent financial statements to obtain favorable loan terms and insurance contracts. Last week, an expert witness testified that, over the years, the inflated valuation statements helped the Trump Organization to save about a hundred seventy million dollars in interest costs. Rather than laboring the point, Wallace took Trump through the 2014 Statement of Financial Condition and some of the valuations it contained. The former President, unlike his two eldest sons, ;who last week insisted; that they had nothing to do with coming up with the dubious asset valuations, admitted that he went over some of the figures with Allen Weisselberg, the chief financial officer of the Trump Organization, and suggested adjustments to some of them. This seemed like a significant and damaging admission, even if Trump didn't seem to think so. He explained that he considered himself uniquely qualified to issue opinions on property valuations, saying: “I think I am probably more expert than anyone else.” (Later in the day, he added: “I can look at buildings and tell you what they're worth.”)

;

;Wallace also brought up two now notorious financial sleights of hand, in which the Trump Organization valued Trump's triplex at Trump Tower as if it were thirty thousand square feet rather than eleven thousand; and valued Mar-a-Lago, Trump's Florida estate, as if it were a private residence even though he had obtained a tax easement by agreeing to use it exclusively as a social club.

;
;
;

;Trump always has an answer, however implausible it is. In the case of the Trump Tower triplex, he conceded that an error had been made, but he claimed that didn't matter much because of a disclaimer clause in the Statements of Financial Condition, which meant that “you don't have to get sued by the attorney general of New York.” (Judge Engoron has already ruled that this disclaimer clause didn't relieve the Trump Organization of the legal obligation to not deliberately file false financial statements.) In reference to Mar-a-Lago, Trump said that even though he had expressed his intent, in a tax document, to operate the property as a member's club, he wasn't bound to that. “It doesn't say I will,” he said. “It says ;intend;.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The many suppliers that Trump has stiffed over the years, from curtain makers to paint companies to carpenters, know the value of his word, of course. But he hadn't come to court merely to remind everyone how slippery he is. His main goal was to criticize the prosecutors and the judge, and to dismiss the case against him as politically motivated—a claim he's been making, in statements to reporters and in posts on social media, since the trial began five weeks ago. On Monday, he took the opportunity to reprise his arguments from the witness stand. When asked whether he disagreed with Attorney General Letitia James's ;claim that the asset valuations were overstated;, Trump called James “a political hack” who had used the case to further her own political career, adding, “This is a political witch hunt.” Then he turned his venom on Judge Engoron, saying: “He called me a fraud and he doesn't know anything about me. 。 。 。 The fraud is on the court, not on me.”

;

;Judge Engoron seemed caught between wanting to keep Trump from speechifying and not wanting to silence him in a way that might give his lawyers grounds for an appeal. He repeatedly told Trump to answer the questions, and, at one point, he complained: “This is not a political rally.这里是法庭。” Trump ignored these admonitions, and his attorney Chris Kise, a former solicitor general of Florida, backed him up with arguments that appeared to be drawn from a campaign playbook rather than any legal manual. As a former President of the United States, Trump deserved a “little latitude” to say whatever he wanted, Kise told Engoron. He also referred to a ;Times; poll showing Trump leading Joe Biden in battleground states and suggested that he was likely to be reëlected. That had nothing to do with the issues at the heart of the case. Kise, like his client, seemed to be addressing the public rather than the judge.

;After a lunch break, the prosecution scored more legal points. Wallace showed Trump some loan documents with Deutsche Bank and got him to concede that the terms of these loans included the Trump Organization maintaining accurate financial statements, including the Statements of Financial Condition. That was important because one of the things that the prosecutors have to show is that the inflated asset values were something that banks relied on. It seemed to contradict Trump's earlier claim that banks didn't pay much heed to the financial statements.

;

;After about four hours on the witness stand, Trump was dismissed. Outside the courtroom, he stopped briefly in front of reporters to say, once again, that the case is “a scam.” Kise also spoke to reporters, and essentially conceded that Trump's defense strategy is political rather than legal. “He's told everyone the facts,” Kise said. “Now that the American people know what's going on, maybe something will change.” James, when she emerged, said that Trump “rambled, he hurled insults, but we expected that,” and she added, “I will not be bullied.” The attorney general also said the documentary evidence proved that the former President had falsely inflated his assets to enrich himself and his family. The prosecution will rest its case on Wednesday, after the testimony of Trump's daughter Ivanka. ♦
